section.title: Complex Numbers
section.introduction: Up to this point, all the mathematical work you have done has involved using real numbers. In this section, we will work with a new set of numbers called complex numberscomplex numbers. It should be noted that the real numbers are actually a subset of the complex numbers!

subsection.title: Motivation
subsection.p:
Let's start by providing some background as to where complex numbers arise from. Suppose that we want to solve for the x-intercepts of f(x) = x^2 -2x + 2. We can use the quadratic formula to obtain the intercepts, but when we do so we obtain
x = \frac{-(-2) \pm \sqrt{(-2)^2-4(1)(2)}}{2(1)} = \frac{2 \pm \sqrt{-4}}{2}.
Notice that \sqrt{-4} is not a real number. As a result, f(x) = x^2 -2x + 2 has no real x-intercepts. This can be also be verified graphically since the graph of f(x) = x^2 - 2x + 2 never crosses the x-axis. (INSERT GRAPH)

section.subsection:
Imaginary Numbers Even though the square root of a negative number is not a real number, we can still work with it. To do so, we need to first define the imaginary unitimaginary number.
Imaginary Unit
The imaginary unit i is defined as i = \sqrt{-1} or i^2 = -1.
It should be noted that the letter i is used to represent a constant, not a variable! With i, we can now define imaginary numbersimaginary numbers.
Imaginary Numbers
Let a > 0 be a real number. Then, \sqrt{-a} = \sqrt{a}\sqrt{-1} = \sqrt{a}i.
Let's look at an example. Consider sqrt{-4}. Then,
\sqrt{-4} \amp= \sqrt{4(-1)} \amp= \sqrt{4}\sqrt{-1} \amp = sqrt{4}i \amp = 2i .
Here are more examples of imaginary numbers 5i, \frac{2}{3}i, -24i, and \sqrt{15}i.

Complex Numbers Recall that when were solving for the x-intercepts of f(x) = x^2 -2x + 2, we obtained the following values for x using the quadratic formula:
x = \frac{2\pm \sqrt{-4}}{2}.
Using our knowledge of imaginary numbers, we find that x = \frac{2\pm 2i}{2} which implies that x = 1 + i or 1 - i. These x-values are examples of complex numberscomplex numbers.
Complex Numbers
A complex number can be written in the form
z = a + bi
where a and b are real numbers. Here, a is called the real part and b is called the imaginary part.
From this definition, we can observe that all real numbers are complex numbers with imaginary part is 0. Also, a complex number whose real part is 0 is called a pure imaginary number.
The real and imaginary parts of a complex number cannot be combined. Hence, two complex numbers are equal if and only if their real parts equal and their imaginary parts are equal.
Equality of Complex Numbers
Two complex numbers z = a+bi and w = c+di are equal if and only if a = c and b = d.
